data.name: No unknown variables!
data.description:
Task

We are given a python code snippet as a single text. Your task is to execute this code and return a dictionary which contains all variable (and function, class, etc.) names that were defined meanwhile, in format (`variable_name : value`).
You can use the built in `exec` statement. However, there are two additional requirements while parsing the code: 1. The code snippet may refer to any previously defined variable from the global scope. 2. The code snippet may also refer to *undefined* variables. Such variables has to be evaluated as a string `~name~` where `name` stands for the undefined variable name. Note that an undefined identifier itself should not be part of the resulting dictionary (unless it gets redefined later in the code snippet). A python identifier consists of alphanumerical characters and potentially underscore (i.e. matches regexp `[a-zA-Z0-9_]+`) and must not start with a digit.

Example

Assume there is a predefined variable `predefined=42`, but identifer `undefined` is undefined. If the input code is the following, def f(): return predefined-2 x = 25 y = f() z = undefined the return dictionary should be something like {'f':, 'x':25, 'y':40, 'z':'~undefined~'}
